entry.title: Satellite-derived irradiance maps
entry.content: Satellite-derived irradiance data has several benefits over ground-measured irradiance despite its lower accuracy. The main advantages include a large geographical coverage (continents), long-timespan (multiple decades), and low cost.

entry.title: Overview of solar radiation monitoring stations
entry.content: Ground-measured solar irradiance data is extremely valuable and critical for benchmarking solar radiation products and understanding the long-term trend in the radiation budget. However, there are only a few hundred high-quality stations globally due to high costs and maintenance requirements. Currently, it is difficult to identify where the nearest solar radiation station is located, as there is no overview of stations worldwide. In this blog, I suggest solving this issue by creating a simple catalog/database of available high-quality radiation stations.

entry.title: Fixing your git mess
entry.content: On a day-to-day basis I use GitHub Desktop due to its nice graphical interface and that my git skills are close to zero. Every now and then, I screw things sufficiently up that I don’t know how to fix it and sometimes I don’t even know how I ended up there. At this point, I really just want to go back in time to when my code was working - which is the topic of this blog post.

entry.title: pvlib - a one-stop source for solar resource data
entry.content: This title at least represents the aim of my Google Summer of Code (GSoC) project that I will be completing during the next 10 weeks. In short, I’ll be extending pvlib python’s current iotools functionalities to provide users with easy and standardized access to all major open-source solar resource databases.
